Dear Mr. Jones:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Shay Mavis at (269) 243-2725.

Sincerely,
Barbara A Cote, Licensing Consultant

Type
Allegation A staff member that previously worked at the facility would show
youth pictures of their thongs, nude pictures, and pictures of

information with a youth and after the youth left the facility, they

Investigation Complainant was interviewed via telephone on April 30, 2025,
and reported this information was shared by Youth A while
Complainant was onsite with DHHS Worker 1 for a different

information.
Director was interviewed via telephone on April 30, 2025.
Director stated he did not have any information related to the

Youth B stated after she returned home, Staff 1 picked her up and

Youth B described Youth E being a transgender female at

Youth B denied ever seeing Youth F hug or touch Youth A’s butt.
Youth B described Supervisor as being a good staff and really

Assistant Facility Administrator (AFA) was interviewed via
telephone on May 8, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS Worker
1 who was at the facility. AFA described Supervisor as being to
the point and all business. AFA reported Supervisor would not be
dismissive of any concerns youth would bring to her involving
other youth or staff. AFA stated some of the older youths have
said Supervisor has “favorites.” AFA described Supervisor meets
the youth where they are, and some of the younger youth need
different things because of their age. AFA reported the older
youth in the program see that as favoritism.
AFA described Staff 1 as “immature and young.” AFA reported
there were times when Staff 1 was corrected in the moment on
shift for swearing. AFA stated Staff 1 was not swearing at the
youth but swearing in general conversation. AFA denied being
aware of any of the information from the allegations.
Youth D was interviewed via telephone on May 8, 2025, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker 1 who was at the facility.
4

Youth D reported liking everything about Supervisor. Youth D
stated Supervisor “does her job” and tells youth to stop when
youth are doing something they should not be doing. Youth D
reported she [Youth D] tries not to listen or pay attention to the
other youth at the facility. Youth D denied having any concerns
regarding staff or youth at the facility.
Supervisor was interviewed via telephone on May 8, 2025, in
collaboration with DHHS Worker 1 who was at the facility.
Supervisor stated if there are issues between youth, Supervisor
will pull the youth away from the group and talk about the issue
then do the same with the other youth. Supervisor reported if the
issue is not a threatening act the issue does not always get
documented, just addressed with the youths. Supervisor
described a youth could be marked down on their point sheet,
coached and offered ways to handle the situation better.
Supervisor stated she could not recall Youth A bringing any
concerns to her regarding any youth inappropriately touching
Youth A. Supervisor reported from what she could recall when
Youth A was at the facility it was a “good group of girls” who
worked well together. Supervisor stated she could not recall any
youth from that group being “touchy feeling” with one another.
Supervisor denied being aware of any youth saying they saw
Youth E masturbating, that their underwear was stolen by Youth E
or that Youth E masturbated to the female youth. Supervisor
described Youth E as wanting to be accepted by the group for
being transgender but also was a bit of a loner and was okay with
being away from the group. Supervisor reported if there were
concerns by any youth nothing was brought to her attention.
Supervisor stated she did not work directly with Staff 1.
Supervisor reported seeing Staff 1 during debriefing or breaks.
Supervisor denied any youth bringing concerns to her regarding
Staff 1 being on her cell phone or showing inappropriate pictures
or videos to youth. Supervisor stated she never saw Staff 1 on
her cell phone around the youth or witness any inappropriate
boundaries from Staff 1 towards youth.
Worker 2 was interviewed via telephone on May 13, 2025.
Worker 2 (Youth B’s worker) reported Youth B told Worker 2 she
was spending time with a former staff from a former placement
after being discharged and returning home. Worker 2 stated she
was unaware of any of the allegations and did not have concerns
with Youth B’s placement when Youth B was at the facility.
5

Staff 1 was interviewed face to face at the Evart Police
Department on May 13, 2025, in collaboration with DHHS
Worker and Detective. Staff 1 described being let go from
Osceola Youth Center in December 2024. Staff 1 reported she
was placed on leave prior to being terminated but stated she was
unclear why she was let go. Staff 1 reported Youth C messaged
Staff 1 on social media about six months ago. Staff 1 denied
responding to Youth C. Staff 1 stated she kept in contact with
Youth B after Youth B left the facility.
Staff 1 stated she recalled getting her hair braided by youth (did
not say what youth) when working at the facility. Staff 1 was
made aware of the allegations by Detective and asked if it was
possible the youth could have seen those type of pictures and
videos on Staff 1’s cell phone. Staff 1 stated she did not think it
was possible, but the pictures probably exist. Staff 1 asked why
she would open something like that in front of the youth. Staff 1
reported pictures and videos exist on her phone but denied
showing them [Youth A, Youth B, and Youth C]. Staff 1 stated,
“everyone has those kinds of pictures on their phone.” Staff 1 was
unclear in what she was describing and asked for an attorney.
Staff 1 was informed by Detective he wanted to provide her the
opportunity to provide her side of the story, and he would be
sending his report into the prosecutor for charges. The interview
with Staff 1 was ended due to Staff 1 asking for an attorney.

She reported that there were pictures of [Staff 1] nude, with

reported that she heard that [Youth B] got caught in [Staff

[Youth C] reported that she also heard that [Staff 1] was

• Email from Worker 1 (Youth A’s worker) dated 5/02/25.
Worker 1 reported she was not aware of any of Youth A’s

• Social Work Contact from Worker 2 (Youth B’s worker)
dated 12/17/24. “[Youth B's] father contacted DHHS last
night at 4am and said [Youth B] took off with some people

• Supervisor’s personnel file. There were three records of
verbal warnings: two for absences/showing up late to work
and one for falling asleep on shift. Supervisor completed
policy and procedure training most recently on 6/14/2024.
• Staff 1’s personnel file. Employee Separation Report dated
12/09/24 due to Staff 1 bringing a vape into the facility.
• Osceola Youth Center Provision of an Abuse Free
Environment/Youth Rights Policies and Procedures. Policy
documents, “All youth placed in a Youth Opportunity facility
has the right to be safe, treated with respect, have their
time in placement remain confidential and private, be free
7

from abuse, exploitation, retaliation, humiliation, and
neglect.”
• Osceola Youth Center Standards of Conduct Policy. Policy
documents, “Unauthorized use of telephones, or other
company-owned equipment; Using company equipment for
purposes other than business (i.e. playing games on
computers or personal Internet usage). Staff are always
expected to maintain ethical and professional behavior.
This includes the expectation that staff are to interact with
youth in a manner promoting their emotional and physical
safety while incorporating trauma responsive practices.”
Analysis The facility is found in noncompliance as per Youth A, Youth B,
Youth C, and Staff 1 interviews, Staff 1 was showing inappropriate
photos and videos to the youth while working, and Face Timing
Youth B after Youth B was discharged from the facility.
The facility is found in compliance regarding allegations of Youth
A’s underwear being stolen and Youth E masturbating to female
youth as Youth B, Youth C, Youth D, and Supervisor’s interviews
provided no information to confirm either of these situations
occurred. In addition, interviews with Supervisor, Youth B, Youth
C and Youth D provided no information Youth A was being
touched on the waist and buttocks while staff failed respond to
correct the behavior.
Conclusion Repeat Violation Established

is recommended that the current license status be continued.
